history.content: I took it with Kubi in Fall 19 and expect the workload to be similar with Stoica and Ghodsi. Your "weekly" work will consist of reading ~2-3 papers per class and writing a short reflection/summary per paper. If you don't have experience reading research papers, this will take you some time to digest the information, so do not be surprised if you spend several hours a week reading the papers. Other than that the main goal of the class is to perform research throughout the semester and submit a final conference style paper and deliver a presentation. It is up to you how you spend your time over the semester, but you should definitely not leave the project until the very end. Taking grad courses as an undegrad is a great experience, but I would not treat it as a class that you can put off, simply because you have other priorities, i.e. midterms, projects, problem sets.

<md>I'm presently enrolled in CS262A for next semester, and wanted to ask if anyone here has taken it and can comment on the workload. I'm trying to determine how much time I'll have to take additional classes and do extracurriculars next semester.</md>
history.subject: CS262A Workload?
